article.headline: Panthers take 8-game win streak to Big Dance
article.linkText: N. Iowa works double OT to win MVC final
article.story: ST. LOUIS (AP) -- Another big game from Ben Jacobson put Northern Iowa in the NCAA tournament for the first time in 14 years. Jacobson tied his career high with 26 points and hit two 3-pointers in the second overtime, leading Northern Iowa to the Missouri Valley Conference tournament title with a 79-74 win over Southwest Missouri State on Monday night. He had 23 points, tying his season best to that point, in a semifinal victory over Wichita State. "He's got some big shoulders," teammate David Gruber said. "He had to carry us the majority of the night, and when a guy like that steps up it makes everybody want to play harder." Gruber added 12 points and eight rebounds and Pete Schmit had 10 points for Northern Iowa (21-9), which won its first Valley championship and the automatic NCAA berth that goes with it. The second-seeded Panthers have an eight-game winning streak and will be making their first NCAA appearance since 1990. Northern Iowa was picked to finish sixth in the preseason poll. "I knew at the beginning of the season that we were capable of winning this tournament," guard Schmit said. "This is the vision I had when I transferred here." Point guard Merrill Andrews had 20 points and 10 rebounds for Southwest Missouri (19-14), the fifth seed. The Bears beat top-seeded and 24th-ranked Southern Illinois in the semifinals on Sunday and defeated fourth-seeded Creighton in the quarterfinals, and made their first appearance in the title game since 2000. "When you get this close to getting to the tournament, it's going to sting and hurt for a long time," Andrews said. "We fought hard, but they did what they had to do to win." Northern Iowa has beaten Southwest Missouri State two straight times, including a 64-59 victory at home Feb. 11, after losing 14 in a row. Southern Illinois (25-4) also figures to get an NCAA bid, giving the Valley two spots in the tournament for the ninth time in 11 years. Southwest Missouri State rallied from a 14-point deficit in the final 11:40 of regulation, with Anthony Shavies scoring eight of his 12 points in an 18-4 run that tied it at 48 with 4:44 to go. Both teams struggled the rest of regulation, and Erik Crawford's bid for a game-winning shot from the lane with 3 seconds to go connected only with the backboard. "We did what we've been doing all tournament long, we let teams get out to a little bit of a lead and then we turn it on," Andrews said. "But in the end they made about two more plays than we did." Northern Iowa was 9-for-11 at the free throw line in the first overtime, but Schmit missed one of two with 14 seconds to go to open the door. Andrews scored in the lane with 3.7 seconds left to tie it at 62 and Jacobson's shot from just past center court was well short at the buzzer. Two free throws by Blake Ahearn at the start of the second overtime gave Southwest Missouri State its first lead, at 64-62, since the Bears got the first basket of the game. But consecutive 3-pointers by Jacobson and Matt Schneiderman, the last with 58.6 seconds to go, gave Northern Iowa a 73-66 lead and the Bears never got closer than four the rest of the way. "You know, we could have hung our heads when they came back on us," Jacobson said. "We took charge and put them down and got the win."
